title: meghan markle racism press bigotry
story: By “they” I mean the liberal-Left commentariat, the people who hate Brexit, hate ordinary people and have, for some reason, grown to love our departing royals, Prince Harry and Meghan.This past  hours they have closed ranks around the couple, who have announced they plan to keep their royal titlesbut leave behind their royal duties — like some woke version of the Queen’s Guard.They have chastised anyone outraged by the staggering entitlement shown by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who have essentially said they want the status but none of the responsibilities of monarchy.They insist the poor couple have been driven out by racism.British author Afua Hirsch, writing in the New York Times, decries the “racist treatment of Meghan” in the Press.She says it is hardly a surprise Meghan has walked away from a nation with a Prime Minister “whose track record includes overtly racist statements” and a “Brexit project linked to native nationalism”.Boris Johnson has no such track record and the only people linking Brexit to native nationalism are elitist, upper-crust Remainers like Hirsch.But no matter. Why let reality spoil the narrative These claims made about the “racist” treatment of Meghan at the hands of the British Press are incredibly thin.The same non-examples are recycled over and over again. You have probably seen them quoteda thousand times.There is that Daily Mail piece from , when Harry and Meghan were first dating, that said she was “ straight outta Compton”.At the time, Meghan’s mother Doria Ragland lived in nearby Crenshaw, LA.Hirsch says this was an attempt to link Meghan with “racialised forms of crime”, meaning gangs.That is one hell of a reach. The piece was clearly just playing on the dference in Harry and Meghan’s social backgrounds.If Harry had been dating a white, working-class woman from Manchester’s Moss Side, I dare say the Mail would have done something similarly silly.Another favourite is that weird throwaway line Boris Johnson’s sister Rachel wrote, in a laudatory piece on Meghan, about the mixed-race American actress bringing some “rich and exotic DNA” to the pale Windsor bloodline. That is more cringey than racist.Several pieces have cited a single phrase in a Sarah Vine column for the Mail — she said she had a “niggling worry” about the royal couple’s engagement photo — as a bigoted dog whistle. That is, quite frankly, mental.Such is the lack of actual examples of the Press being racist about Meghan.The only leg this argument has left to stand on is that the sheer volume of criticism sent Meghan’s way was disproportionate.Racism is the only explanation for it. It’s an argument based purely on unveriable speculation and imputing motives. It is also b*****ks.When the couple first got together, the coverage was gushing across the board.It was only when Meghan and Harry started on their ious virtue-signalling cru-sades — such as jetting around to lecture on climate change — that people’s backs went up.That the couple had already been beefing with the Press probably didn’t help either.In , way before Meghan became a figure in our culture wars, Harry issued a remarkable statement rebuking journalists for the “racial undertones” of their pieces.That these privileged royals, kept in the lap of luxury at taxpayers’ expense, began to develop a deep-seated victim complex only heightened the resentment towards them.Last year, Meghan told ITV public le was a “struggle” and she was shocked that “not many people have askedI’m OK”. Poor princess.This picture of privilege is who the liberal Left has spent the best part of three years defending.Even supposed republicans have — after a bit of anti-royal throat-clearing — defended Harry and Meghan to the hilt and helped con- struct this absurd narrative that they are the victims of establishment racism.This says far more about the prejudices of liberal-Left commentators than it does about the tabloid Press. They routinely suggest Meghan’s supposed mistreatment in Brexit Britain is no coincidence.They think Britain is a foul place full of foul people, brainwashed by foul news- papers to hate the wonderful Duchess of Sussex and the brilliant European Union.What the liberal elite’s Meghanmania shows us is that, for all their posturing against right-wingers, monarchy and the old aristocracy, they are title: meghan markle and harrys security costs are spiralling out of control
story: The bill for the Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s protection team currently stands at about £, a year, and is picked up by the taxpayer.Now, senior police are worried the couple’s demand to be seen as “internationally protected people” could see the royal bodyguard budget soar even further.The Times today reported that the costs are spiralling out of control, and quoted a top cop who said the royal couple did not understand the seriousness of what they were demanding.The former Scotland Yard chief said they “have not thought out the security implications of their move and have put the Met in an impossible situation”.Scotland Yard is already facing an uphill battle to train enough specialist officers to cope with royal family security.A report last year revealed the Met has found it “extremely dficult” to obtain the necessary training courses to increase officer numbers, leading to a “reliance on overtime”.Staying in Canada over Christmas, Harry and Meghan were accompanied by six armed Met officers at all times.However, given the   nature of security this meant ten officers were needed with replacements flown out throughout.Costs also soared in South Africa, where a fleet of armoured Land Rover Discoverys was shipped to because sufficient secure vehicles could not be sourced locally.The cost of flights for protection officers rose from £. million in - to £. million in -.Hotel stays increased from £. million in - to more than £ million in -.Anti-monarchy group Republic estimates the cost of royal security to the taxpayer at a massive £ million per year.It comes as the Prime Minister backed the Queen to sort the row.

title: scarlett moffatt wowcher mystery deal
story: The Im a Celeb winner posted on Instagram from Barcelona where she is fronting a campaign for the online discount firm.She said: New Year’s Resolutions: self love! Be more spontaneous! Travel more! If you’re wanting to spontaneously travel more - Book a mystery holiday for £ and you could end up in New York, Bali, Disneyland or even Barcelona like me! .Reality star Scarlett also posted loved-up snaps of her and cop boyfriend Scott Dobinson in Barcelona for their one-year anniversary.She captioned one: I still cant believe this trip is £. One of the many reasons I love @wowcher.But the mystery deal has been slammed by furious travellers claiming they were forced to shell out more than the advertised £ deal.Holidaymakers are put into a Lottery-style draw for holidays ranging from two to seven nights based on two people sharing.Destinations include New York, Dubai, Las Vegas, Bali, Thailand, Ibiza, Rome and Disneyland Paris but customers dont know where they are going until after they have booked.The deal includesflights and a hotel stay - but is based on departures from Stansted, Gatwick, Southend, Luton and Heathrow.This means some customers end up paying over the odds when they wish to change airports, flight times or add checked baggage to their trip.One Wowcher customer wrote: Or you could or you could end up having just spent £ on a trip to Dublin for  people for my daughters th birthday and be totally shafted and not get what we’ve paid for. Currently waiting for a manager to ring me from @wowcher but wouldn’t touch this company with a barge pole !!!The trips include flights and accommodation, and some are even all-inclusive.You have to buy at least two vouchers, at £ each, and then you go into a draw to win your destination.Everyone will get a holiday, but you just dont know where youre going until the draw happens.But customers who want to fly from an airport that isnt Stansted, Gatwick, Southend, Luton and Heathrow will have to pay extra.It also costs more to change flight times or dates.One user said: My friend did it for us. We ended up with Venice! But then they were arguing and trying to change it to Budapest.Then the hotel they wanted to put us in was a total e !!! Also needed more money for the flights. Was a total joke ! We ended up not going.Another said: Same happened to me! She should stop promoting it as I only did it on her recommendation as usually don’t fall for it.I’m fuming as I paid more with the vouchers than I wouldI booked it myself. Guy on the phone was pushy for a decision.Last year, a fuming customer accused Wowcher of running a scam after booking a £ mystery holiday deal - only for the destinations to be sold out.Twitter user Will, , originally paid £ per person for a weekend break with his girlfriend.Their holiday was set to be between July and August, with the deal costing slightly more than the normal £ as it was peak time.However, despite being told initially that they would be going to Venice, they were then told it had sold out, and would have to go another time of year.Some lucky punters do end up with a dream holiday though - one man was lucky enough to pay £ for the mystery holiday and ended up spending four nights in Dubai.The Sun Online has contacted Wowcher and Scarletts people for comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour leadership rivals turn on keir starmer
story: Two of the five candidates have made it clear they are not looking for a moderate new leader to steady to ship after Jeremy Corbyns devastating defeat.Leadership candidate Lisa Nandy urged members of the Labour party not to go for the easy choice of a moderate candidate.She warned it was not the time to steady the ship or play it safe at her launch yesterday.I am obviously not a candidate that represented safety or stability. I dont look like the leaders that weve chosen in the past and I suspect I dont sound like them either she said.The MP for Wigan did not name Sir Keir but according to the i newspaper, backbencher MPs said her comments were a dig at the millionaire London MP.Remainer Jess Phillips also steered clear of giving Sir Keir any praise when asked about who she would like to be the next leaderit was not her, giving her backing to Ms Nandy.The former barrister faces criticism of being too metropolitan and middle class to be Labour leader.He claimed he had working class roots and said my background isnt what they think it is.Rebecca Long-Bailey, seen as the continuity Corbyn candidate, came second best on  followed by Ms Nandy on .Sir Keir steamrolled the other candidates, after receiving  nominations by fellow MPs and MEPs in the first round of the leadership contest.Both Ms Philips and Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry only just secured enough nominations to get through to the second round, with  colleagues backing them.The candidates will now have to secure  nominations from almost  constituency Labour parties, or three from affiliated members - atleast two of which have to be trade unions.Sir Keir has already been given the support from the biggest trade union, Unison.Top corbynista and boss of Unite trade union Ken McCluskey has refused to give his support to any candidate yet, saying it will be announced next week.He denied claims from the BBC he had been impressed by Lisa Nandy and has been tipped to support Ms Long-Bailey.Lisa Nandy has been backed by GMB trade union.The candidates will take place in a series of hustings on January , and have until February  to secure enough nominations to get them over the line.The final ballot by Labour party members will open on February  and the winner will be announced April . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: women plagued ptsd after miscarriage signs
story: One in six who lose a baby in the early stages are plagued by the mental health condition, new findings show.The same was true for women who had an ectopic pregnancy - where the embryo starts to grow outside the womb and so is not viable.The largest study of its kind, shows one month after a loss nearly one in three women suffered post-traumatic stress, while one in four experienced severe to moderate anxiety.Meanwhile, one in ten were plagued by moderate to severe depression.Nine months later, experts at Imperial College London and KU Leuven in Belgium, found  per cent of women had PTSD,  per cent had anxiety and six per cent had depression.Professor Tom Bourne, lead author from the Tommys National Centre for Miscarriage Research at ICL has called for immediate improvements in the care women receive following an early-stage pregnancy loss.Pregnancy loss affects up to one in two women, and for many women it will be the most traumatic event in their le, he said.This research suggests the loss of a longed-for child can leave a lasting legacy.And result in a woman still suffering post-traumatic stress nearly a year after her pregnancy loss.The consultant gynaecologist said the findings show that treatment in the wake of a miscarriage should change to reflect the severe mental health impact.Recent efforts to encourage people to talk more openly about this very common issue are a step in the right direction, he said.While general support and counselling will help many women, those with signicant post-traumatic stress symptoms require specic treatmentthey are going to recover fully.This is not widely available, and we need to consider screening women following an early pregnancy loss so we can identy those who most need help.One in four pregnancies end in miscarriage - most often before or around  weeks.Estimates suggest there are , miscarriages every year in the UK, and around , emergency admissions for ectopic pregnancies.The latter always results in pregnancy loss, as an embryo grows outside the womb - often in the Fallopian tubes - and is unable to develop.Prof Bourne and his team studied more than  women -  of whom had suffered a miscarriage before  weeks, while  suffered an ectopic pregnancy.The women were all cared for at the Early Pregnancy Assessment Units at three London hospitals - Queen Charlottes and Cha, St Marys and Cha and Westminster.All filled out questionnaires about their emotions and behaviour one month after pregnancy loss - then again at three and nine months later.The researchers compared their answers to those of  women who had healthy pregnancies.The results showed women who experienced healthy pregnancies had signicantly fewer psychological symptoms than those who suffered early pregnancy loss.Those who displayed signs of PTSD told doctors they regularly relived the feelings around the time of their loss.Other signs included:Shes written a radio play about recurrent miscarriage called Little Blue Lines.Sharing her experience, she said: After my first miscarriage I was numb.I did not know how to react or who to approach.I did not knowit was grief that I was feeling, orthat was even a valid response to have about losing something so small.So I tried to believe reassuring words - its not your fault you can try again youve got time its just one of those things.The second time it happened I knew something was wrong immediately, just a faint pink patch in my pants, a slight cramping feeling.Then dread and anxiety at what was to come, and guilt at what I could have done to cause it sadness for myself, but also my husband, my family, my friends who would have to do all those sad faces and texts and calls again.The physical miscarriage was a huge shock, one I was absolutely not prepared for and I will never forget it.I tried to move on as advised. Trying again was full of anxiety that got worse when I fell pregnant for the third time.Happily that resulted in a healthy full term birth, but the first trimester was extremely stressful, for both myself and my husband.I struggled to keep perspective and flitted between wanting this baby more than anything  to wishing I would just bleed and get the awful thing over with and my le back.It was only after my son was born I realised the enormity of what I had been through, and the need to process it - there are support groups at my hospital now but there was nothing available to me at the time - so I wrote about it.Prof Bourne said while they used the questionnaire to identy PTSD, a formal clinical diagnosis would be needed to confirm it.However, he warned that the fact so many women were experiencing symptoms suggests many could be suffering in silence.Dr Jessica Farren, an obstetrician and gynaecologist who also worked on the study, said: Post-traumatic stress can have a toxic effect on all elements of a persons le - title: meghan markle not pitchforked off uk
story: It follows the fortunes, or rather, misfortunes, of Americans who fall in love with foreigners and have just over three months to get married or send them home.A massive leap of faith, it’s usually a matter of days — sometimes hours — before the clash of cultures, personalities, values and expectations make this the television gt that keeps on giving.Perhaps Meghan and Harry should sign up for season eight. For how much did they really know about each other before walking down the aisle Prince William apparently advised his more impetuous brother to wait so he could really get to know his American bride first, but Harry took umbrage and didn’t listen.Perhapshe had, he might have worked out in advance that an independent spirit joining such a restrictive institution wasn’t going to end well.Instead, they leapt before they looked and, with the “-month bride” having packed her bags already, have saddled the -year-old Queen with yet another constitutional crisis.Back in , I wrote a piece defending Meghan after she was criticised by old school friend Ninaki Priddy for being “calculated in the way she handled people and relationships” and a “curator of a beautul le”.But following the lavish baby shower, the jet-setting with A-listers and the swt jettisoning of inconveniently outspoken family members, the latter sentiment now rings true.And, of course, becoming a member of the most famous royal family in the world was the cherry on the top of that beautul le.But Meghan soon discovered it was nothing like the membership of her beloved Soho House.The rooms are draughty, the decor chintzy and, instead of reading the morning papers in your cashmere loungewear, you have to rise early, put on a frock and make your way to some rain-lashed outpost to open the new wing of a community centre where “live your best le” sentiments, however well-meaning, aren’t required.Here’s what is required as a member of the British Royal Family: Turn up on time, shake hands, smile, say little more than “have you come far ” Repeat.Not because the royals don’t have anything to say. They do, and air their views in private.But in public, their job is to shine a light on whatever project they’re visiting, not themselves. To show — via action, not virtue-signalling statements — a strong sense of duty.And inthey get to keep their ious mansions, hundreds of staff, personal bodyguards etc without any whf of civil unrest.That’s the deal.But those still in Meghan’s social circle glowingly describe her as organised, focused, and opinionated — very much an independent woman used to having her voice heard.As Prince Harry told courtiers just before their wedding: “What Meghan wants, Meghan gets.”An admirable quality when it comes to breaking through the glass ceiling of corporate le or securing the best table in the best restaurant, perhaps.But the monarchy is an institution steeped in hundreds of years of tradition, and Meghan — who claimed she “didn’t know much” about Harry when they first met — clearly thought she’d mould it to her way of thinking . . . then rapidly discovered that it ain’t for turning.Not that The Queen didn’t try very hard to accommodate the wants and needs of the newly anointed Duke and Duchess of Sussex.Contrary to royal tradition, they were permitted to keep the christening of baby Archie as a private affair and, despite there being a perfectly nice home at Kensington Palace they could have used, a publicly funded, £.million renovation of Frogmore Cottage was authorised.A “cottage” I might add, that used to be five homes but has now been knocked in to one because they managed to dodge the usual ban that prevents such moves because of the UK’s housing crisis.Shortly after, Prince Charles launched his blueprint to try to solve the dilemma faced by millions of young people struggling to find a home of their own. Oh the irony. And after all that, they now want to use it part-time as they flit back and forth across the Atlantic.Meghan is feeling disillusioned and homesick. We get it, and sympathise.But let’s not pretend, as some claim, that she’s been practically pitchforked off this island by racist bigots.This is not a racist country and, besides, the British public initially greeted her engagement and later marriage to Harry with unbridled joy.We love Harry. He’s a thoroughly decent person and deserves particular praise for the work he’s done with the Armed Forces, both while serving and afterwards.No, the disconnect has come from the fact that Meghan is still a Hollywood celebrity at heart and, consequently, never truly settled in her often boring and restrictive new role.She misses the relative freedom of her old le, not to mention her family and friends.Again, we get it. But was it really necessary to flee these shores asescaping for her le Clearly besotted with her, Harry faces the stark decision of giving her what she wants or losing her for ever. Or perhaps he’s genuinely sick of royal le and wants out too.If so, let’s wave goodbye and wish them luck.But. The have-cake-and-eat-it plan to stop being a “senior royal” and just dip in and out of duties that suit them simply isn’t going to work.SussexRoyal — which Harry and Meghan have registered as an official trademark for everything from “emotional support services” to clothing and magazines — is a title and privilege that comes with duties and conditions attached, not a brand, be it charitable or otherwise.The future of the monarchy depends on the goodwill, support and interest level of the public, and a recent survey showed that, while the majority have no issue with their decision to go, they were strongly against any continued taxpayer funding of their lavish lestyle.So— as early indicators go — The Queen allows Harry and Meghan to call the shots while keeping their royal titles, their taxpayer-funded security and an allowance from the Duchy of Cornwall, then one suspects this will be discussed by students for centuries to come as the turning point at which the British monarchy began its steady decline to irrelevance and, ultimately, abolition.MOVIE mega-star Will Smith popped in to the retirement party of a woman he last met  years ago.Anita Scipio was the receptionist at a US radio station when Will arrived for one of his first interviews as a young actor and he’s never forgotten how nice she was to him.“My favorite moments on the road are the ones where I can connect with people like @anitascipio,” -year-old Will told his Instagram followers before he walked in to the station to give her a hug.In the days before social media, someone who worked at his record company Sony told me that whenever he was in town, Will would tour the building, from post room to boardroom, giving time to everyone.He’s that rare creature, a star on screen and off.Some of today’s petulant slebs should watch and learn.FORMER psychiatric nurse Susan Evans is launching a landmark legal case to challenge consent issues around the provision of puberty blockers and cross-sex hormones for under-s.She argues that children should be protected from “experimental” and “invasive medical treatment”, not least because “some children are referred despite having autism, being homosexual or suffering some form of trauma or sexual abuse”.Speaking on Radio , she added that children as young as nine were being asked to consent “to a completely experimental treatment for which long-term consequences are not known”.But gender ersity advocates warn that “a loss to trans youth is a loss to all”.Time will tell the outcome of her case but, meanwhile, in unrelated comments, I note that the actor Rupert Everett says he spent most of his early childhood wanting “to be a girl”.He adored his mother, aunt and grandmother, didn’t like men, and adds: “I loved necklaces and bras and all those kinds of things.”Then, when he reached , he “didn’t want to be a girl any more. But Mr Johnson wants its chimes to mark the historic moment at pm on January when we leave the EU.House of Commons chiefs yesterday turned down  pro-Brexit MPs’ pleas to reconnect the clock’s bells for Brexit — on grounds of spiralling cost.Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle said the final bill could end up being four times the original estimate, £,, because it would set back ongoing work for weeks.But Brexiteers were left furious, claiming the move has already been authorised twice in the last two months to see the clock bong for Remembrance Sunday as well as New Year’s Eve.Commons chiefs insisted they would need to give contractors two working weeks to reconnect and then test the bells — meaning Brexiteers have until next Monday morning to raise the necessary cash.The PM initially pledged to lead the fundraising charge, during an interview with BBC Breakfast.He said: “We’re working up a plan so people can bung a bob for a Big Ben bong, because everybody knows Big Ben is being refurbished, they seemed to have taken the clapper away.“So we need to restore the clapper in order to bong Big Ben on Brexit night.”Later, the PM’s official spokesman said: “If the public wants Big Ben to bong and the money is raised then that is great. We will make sure that — whatever happens in regard to Big Ben’s bongs — January  is properly marked.”Leading Tory Eurosceptic Mark Francois yesterday pledged £, of his money towards the funding.Calling for others to contribute, Mr Francois said: “I’m sure the BBC can help.  Perhaps the staff of the Today Programme could have a cake sale”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun readers views harry meghan
story: Hundreds of YOU have ­written in with your thoughts, by email and on text.  Here we share some of your views on the Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s split from The Firm.HAVING grown up in the royal household, Prince Harry should know that the HRH title is not compatible with a part-time job.He should be given  days to decide whether he and his we want to keep the titles — with the perks such as taxpayer-funded security and the obligations like being seen at Sandringham at Christmas — or surrender them and have the freedom to do whatever they want.Jim Warren from BathI AM not a university educated person but I do know the meaning of “independence”. Having royal protection, receiving £million a year from the Duchy and having Frogmore ­Cottage at their disposal is not financial independence. Give taxpayers some credit. If you want to leave the UK, don’t expect us to keep you in comfort. Get a job.Peter Jackson from LeedsHARRY should have been given an ultimatum. How disappointing this has all been, when royals openly show that all they think about are themselves. All we have heard is about how Harry will have to pay tax and possibly £,-a-month rent for his “cottage”he leaves.Every low-paid person in this country has to pay tax and for a roof over their head. Why don’t they   If Harry wants to leave then he should be free to do so like anyone  on the understanding that all titles and payments will be forfeited.  It is to be admiredpeople want to stand on their own two feet.Wendy Lively from Hexham, NorthumberlandHOW right to call the Meghan and Harry crisis Megxit. Just like Brexit, it has outraged the nation. But how disappointing that the Queen has shown that selfish couple leniency It will beggar beliefthey are allowed to keep their titles and income yet refrain from royal duties.  What a shame the plain-speaking Prince Philip wasn’t allowed the final say. He’d have sent that arrogant pair on their way with their ears ringing.THERE is no reason why the Sussexes should not lead a more private le and step down — but not at the expense of the country. They should not keep their HRH titles as they have proved they are not royal. Did Meghan Markle join the Royal Family for prestige Mavis Sinfield from Whitstable, KentMEGHAN should be stripped of her title so she can make her way financially independently.  If they still want Frogmore Cottage, she and Harry should sign a lease and pay back the £.million the public paid to refurbish it. They have done more damage than any other royals in the last  years, so give them the obscurity they crave.C Duffy from Stoke-on-TrentTHE QUEEN has missed a golden opportunity to show us how strong she is. She has let Harry and Meghan off the hook and given the despicable couple what they want.I never had any time for royalty yet I did respect the Queen. She’s blown it big time. Workers are paying tax through the nose to pay scavengers Harry and Meghan.JK Bate from Bilston, West MidsShe has given her blessing so allow the couple to live their le as they please, just as you and I would like to. Respect our Queen’s decision.Jay Reeves, Caterham, SurreyPublic feeling now is very much that Meghan can’t have what Meghan wants. We appreciate Her Majesty’s “family” is involved but that family needs a public mandate to survive. Harry and Meghan have totally eroded that mandate.Chris Martin from Rochford, EssexIT seems to me the Queen has capitulated in the Meghan and Harry crisis because she had no choice. She either kicks them out of the Royal Family, which she would never do, or she compromises and we, the taxpayers, are left to pay the bill — albeit through the Duchy of Cornwall — to indulge the pair’s selfishness.Ken Pennington from Stalybridge, CheshireMAKING this announcement on Kate’s birthday, with the Duke of Edinburgh just out of hospital, and refusing to clear it with Prince Charles or the Queen first makes Harry and Meghan look terrically selfish.Marcus Walker from MiddlesboroughTHE Queen looks tired and sad. She doesn’t need this. Grow up, you two!Anon by textI’VE worked for  years. Anything I’ve wanted I’ve had to do overtime and save for. Can I have a refund of my share of Frogmore Cottage William Ensor from BirminghamI’M  and still have to pay tax on my pension just to keep the ignorant young royals happythey don’t want to earn their crust. Kick them out. Meghan has caused all this trouble with the Queen.Bryn from NorthantsTO give Harry and Meghan what they want we should stop all the money they get from the Government and The Duchy of Cornwall. If they get any money from these sources it will upset a lot of the Queen’s subjects.Dave Mashiter  from Exeter, DevonWHY didn’t Harry and Meghan mention these thoughts before a lavish wedding and £.million house ­renovation !Bea from CumbriaHARRY and Meghan won’t need money from the ­public purse. Fergie has made a fortune living off of her title.Terry Smith from Gillingham, KentHARRY touting Meghan’s voiceover skills is no better than Fergie touting meet-ups with Andrew several years ago to earn a few bob.  He and Meghan should renounce everything here — titles, homes and security — and go to Canada as ordinary citizens.They have enough contacts to make a good living on their own and should leave the hard-working royals to get on with the job that they do so well.Sue Sutherland from HullI AM disgusted at how Harry and Meghan are behaving towards their family. In my opinion it’s all about ego.  Meghan waltzed in here expecting to eclipse William and Kate in the public’s eyes but she badly misjudged the whole scenario. She is used to being the centre of attention and had her nose put out of joint as she soon realised she would always come second best, and that doesn’t suit her.I’m surprised Harry, who has been under scrutiny since birth, is turning against the media. He is obviously being led around by the nose.  Let them go to Canada, without any support from the British taxpayer. They are not wanted here.Jean Spurr, address withheldHOW dare “’woke” leftie liberals claim the Sussexes are being driven out by racism  It’s nonsense and a disgraceful slur on this country. Harry and Meghan were showered with love by the public and Press until they began to whine and Meghan, in particular, realis­ed royal le can be dull and constraining.Then, to add insult to injury, they failed to give the Queen any notice about stepping back as senior royals. This wonderful woman has devoted every waking minute to the service of this country for  years, and to treat her with such disrespect was beyond the pale. It’s an awfully sad state of affairs, for Harry in particular, but racism is not to blame.Neil Coppendale from Shoreham-by-Sea, West SussexWITH what happened to Diana, I understand Harry wanting to step away from the spotlight but I get the feeling Meghan calls the shots. Maybe the Hollywood princess didn’t like the work of a real royal.With their brand name, they will still have an easy le but with one prince gone, Harry has selfishly put a lot on William’s shoulders.Matthew Wilson from WolverhamptonIT was most disingenuous of Meghan Markle not to think that her le would be seismically changed when she married a Prince.It is obvious that she does not possess the required qualities of allegiance to the crown and should therefore renounce the title of HRH and revert to becoming known as simply Meghan Markle once more.  I sincerely hope Prince Harry will one day realise the hurt and damage they have caused to Her Majesty and their once adoring public.John Burton from Worksop, NottsALREADY it has come to light that Harry and Meghan actually intend to live in LA and not Canada at all. How many more lies have we been told  Yet more proof that what the controlling Meghan wants, she gets.Watch out, Harry. Once she gets all she wants you will be the next person cut out of her le.Eddie Derby by textHARRY is out of his depth and is being used. I predict that within five years he will be unceremoniously dumped by fame-chasing Meghan.Roger Stilgoe from BirminghamIF Harry wants to branch out, what’s the problem  It’s not like he has abdicated.Patrick from LoughboroughMEGHAN chose to marry into the most famous family on Earth then moans about wanting privacy.Stefan Badham from PortsmouthFor more than  years this country has been multi-racial, as Prince Harry will know from our history. For Meghan’s fans to play the race card when she’s only had a warm welcome since she arrived is just ridiculous.Whatever the future holds for them many will wish them well, hoping their time in Canada is not funded by the public.Jack Amer from NorfolkOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: american designer shoes cake
story: Chris, , carefully pipes fake buttercream and sticks tiny decorations on the £ to £ shoes in Florida.He even uses baking tools like piping bags, tips and acrylic mediums of dferent types to get the texture and the decoration that give the shoes a three dimensional aspect.Chris says, “I love cake and waffles so much that I put them on shoes.I really thought it would be a dferent idea to try for women’s heels. Who doesn’t love sweets ”Chris, , from Orlando in Florida, started making the dessert-inspired shoes in  - but has recently seen an explosion of interest from customers.He added: “The handmade shoes are only online and we have a few boutiques that sell our manufactured items.Our shoes can be customised and most of our orders are wedding orders and can be altered from top to bottom.”Chris says the idea of making the shoes came from his stint at college where he used to create sneakers for students and try to make the texture look realistic such as metal, wood, water and even skin.“I always enjoyed the challenge of making things seem like something they weren’t.“I started Shoe Bakery with the same idea in mind by taking desserts and using them as inspiration for women’s heels.I experimented for a while before getting started and I notice that this could work.“It was shared on Facebook, and grew so fast within a week and then we started to grow on Instagram very quickly from everyone sharing our pictures.”Looks like a cake walk.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ross clark huawei 5g network
story: This is a company that has brought us the technology of an iPhone but at a fraction of the cost.I am no protectionist and I don’t fear the Chinese.When it comes to selling us consumer goods, I am more than happy to welcome China’s companies into the country to compete with British, European or US-made products.But it is a very dferent matter when it comes to allowing a Chinese company to build Britain’s next- generation broadband network — with all the security issues that raises.Unbelievably, the Government is seriously considering doing just this.Yesterday, the Prime Minister — who is due to make a decision next month on whether to award Huawei a contract to build parts of Britain’s G network — indicated that he is inclined to give the company the nod.Critics, he said, needed to suggest which other company ought to be allowed to do the work.I am sorryI am a little ignorant on this point. While I have bought several mobile phones, I have never gone shopping for an entire telecoms network.But surely there must be other potential contractors. Don’t we have a telecoms industry of our own It doesn’t say much for the Government’s privatisation of BTit is not in the running for this sort of work.What about our own Vodafone, which I thought was one of the world leaders in mobile phone technology Evendepriving Huawei of the work meant we had to wait a little longer or pay a little extra to download a movie to our phones, that would surely be a reasonable price to pay for protecting national security.And national security policy really is at stake.Yesterday the US reaffirmed that allowing Huawei to build our G network — even parts of it which are deemed to be low- risk — would be “madness” and could compromise the willingness of the US to share vital intelligence with Britain in future.This didn’t come in one of Donald Trump’s notorious am tweets but from officials working for Matt Pottinger, the US deputy national security adviser, and Robert Blair, special representative for international telecommunications policy.That they took the trouble to visit London to warn of the dangers we could be getting ourselves into ought to be seen as a red flag on Huawei’s involvement in our G network.Surely, the importance of being able to share intelligence with our most important ally should rank above pure considerations of cost.Australia has already blocked the Chinese firm from its G network.Yet here, the head of MI Sir Andrew Parker said he had “no reason” to think Britain’s intelligence partnership with the US would sufferinvolvement from the Chinese firm was given the green light.But Defence Secretary Ben Wallace underlined at the weekend that the US administration has threatened to cut off some intelligenceBritain approves Huawei’s involvement in G.He said: “Those things will be taken into account when the Government collectively decides to make a decision on it.”Our own Government — as it has been doing since Theresa May’s day — insists that only parts of the G contract would be awarded to Huawei.It would not be allowed to work on security-critical areas.But that isn’t good enough. Such is the complexity of modern telecommunications networks that it would be impossible to be sure that systems installed in one part of the network were not enabling data to be obtained from another.Whoever designs and builds a telecommunications system gains the power to interfere with it, or even switch it off, should it feel inclined.Of course, with modern communications a huge amount of damage can be done from afar.Evenwe are confident our broadband network is secure now, we can’t be certain that would remain the case.A company which installs a telecommunications network will necessarily continue to be involved in maintaining and upgrading the network it had designed and installed.We have to be absolutely sure the network is not being used for some underhand purpose.Huawei denies that it is controlled by the Chinese state, and has threatened to sue commentators in France whom it alleges have made that claim.But the precise relationship between Huawei and the Chinese state is hardly the point.What is certain is that China is not a democracy and there is always going to be a security issue when it comes to involving its industrial giants in sensitive work here.We would not allow a Chinese company, say, to build fighter jets for the RAF or to construct our radar defence system.This kind of work is rightly the preserve of contractors on whom we can rely totally, even in times of international conflict.Such is the importance of telecommunications in military and civil defence that we now have to think of mobile networks in the same light.The Government has been warning for years that cyber warfare is the big coming threat.In  it published a Strategic Defence Review which defined cyber attack as a “Tier One” threat alongside terrorism.Last November, the US and Taiwanese held a joint exercise in fending off a major cyber attack on Taiwan.At the time the Taiwanese Cyber Security Agency said it was the subject of an astonishing million cyber attacks every month, half of which came from the Chinese mainland.So why, then, is our own Government even considering commissioning a Chinese company to install a telecommunications network Of course, Boris Johnson is right to make it clear he is not Donald Trump’s poodle.We don’t have to take notice of everything the Americans say, on defence, trade or anything .But when it comes to our closest ally warning us that it might not want to share intelligence with us in futurewe let a Chinese company build our G network, we very much do need to take notice.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP title: neglected pets saved charities
story: The three-year-old pup was nursed back to health, doubling her weight to st at an animal rescue centre in Northumberland. Like Tiggy, with help from similarly devoted charities, these ill-treated animals have all pulled through – with tails that end happily, you might say.THEN: The mastf was found by RSPCA officers in June  suffering from the skin condition mange, caused by a parasite bite. Scrum’s skin was tender and raw and needed extensive veterinary treatment, say his rescuers.NOW: Scrum has made an amazing recovery and is back to full health at the RSCPA’s Bristol Animal Rescue Centre. He is now looking for his forever home, soyou can offer him a loving environment, get in touch with bristolarc.org.uk.THEN: When Trooper was found on the streets in  his fur was so matted that he couldn’t walk, as one of his legs had become fused to his ear.  The Lhasa apso – a breed from Tibet – was taken in by the Dogs Trust Leeds rehoming centre, where wardens said he was the worst case of neglect they had seen in  years.NOW: After being sheared under general anaesthetic, Trooper proved to be a trouper and was completely healed and ready for a new start in just a few weeks. Now in a foster home in Halax, he enjoys several walks a day and loves playing in his new garden.THEN: Hunter the kitten was abandoned last March in a cat carrier with a sign that read: “Help me please”.  At just five months old, the pitul puss had deformed front legs, straggly fur and a completely bald tail and he was severely underweight and malnourished. Yet even during intensive-care treatment at Battersea Dogs  Cats Home, Hunter loved cuddles from his carers.NOW: After specialist medical treatment for his front legs, and with his majestic coat grown back, Hunter is fully back to health and has begun a happier chapter in his le after being adopted by a family.THEN: The Shetland pony was found by the RSPCA in Godalming, stuck in mud up to her stomach, gravely underweight and with no food or grass to graze on. Originally from Dorset, Tink was left alone in a field and kept separate from other ponies.NOW: Tink has since gained weight and is looking so fit that she was chosen to be in a Christmas RSPCA ad.  Her carers say Tink loves food so much that they have to be strict with her diet.  Patricia Spargo, of the RSPCA, added: “She constantly makes us all laugh as she is so expressive. You can just see what she is thinking all over her face.”THEN: Last February the frail West Highland terrier was found having lost most of his coat, and skin and ear infections had been left untreated by his then owners. The itchy fungal virus needed a vet’s attention but instead Archie had been left to suffer in pain.NOW: While at a Dogs Trust vet’s appointment Archie was spotted by Westie fan Anne-Marie, who was looking for a dog to join her family. He has now fully recovered from his problems, thanks to medical treatment and the devotion of his foster family.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu trade deal fishing rights
story: Eurocrats hardened their position on demanding continued access to our waters after Boris Johnson vowed not to extend the transition period beyond December .The EU said talks on fisheries will now have a “direct link” to thrashing out tarf and quota free trade on goods.Previously, the EU had stated access for its vessels would be secured “within the context of the overall economic partnership”.But Mr Johnson’s insistence the UK will quit the transition come what may at the end of this year has sparked concern in Brussels.Eurocrats believe only a “bare bones” trade deal on goods will be done by then and want to play hardball over fishing for maximum leverage.In a briefing to EU diplomats, Michel Barnier’s team said any deal on “reciprocal” access would be of “unprecedented scale and scope”.The pact would include agreements on quotas that European fishermen can land in our waters and a clause to protect their livelihoods.EU negotiators want to get it done by July  this year — the date by which the UK must say whether or not it plans to extend the transition.EU trade chief Phil Hogan has suggested fishing rights may be secured in a “trade-off” with the UK over market access for the City of London.Eurocrats argue access for EU boats cannot be separated from tarf-free terms for British fish products on EU markets.The PM has vowed to take back control of UK fishing waters when the transition period ends.Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen warned the PM he wont be able to “have his cake and eat it” in trade talks. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry meghan no justification 2 3m
story: There can be no justication for the young quitters still getting any of their annual £.million from the Duchy of Cornwall which Prince Charles controls.The Family seem to think of that vast £billion estate as their private fortune. But it has simply been inherited by the eldest son of the monarch since . If the Royals are abolished — because, say, public support dries up — the estate and its profits revert to the nation.It is the nation’s property, Charles merely its . So there must be complete transparency over how he spends the millions it makes, just as there is for the Sovereign Grant paid direct to the Royals by the Government.We’ll say this too. UK taxpayers are fed up enough . . . but spare a thought for the Canadians. Why should THEY fund the Sussexes’ security till the couple are good and ready to move to LA They made their bed. They can lie in it. And they’re rich enough already to pay their own bills.REMEMBER Remainers claiming Boris Johnson would be Trump’s poodle  How’s that prediction working out On Iran he has attacked the President for ditching the multinational nuclear deal without a replacement.On Huawei he is demanding to know America’s alternative, since they are so violently opposed to the Chinese giant building our G network. The Sun ­happens to agree Huawei is a risk, but at least Boris is speaking his mind.And the PM is at odds with Trump over America’s reluctance to extradite death crash driver Anne Sacoolas.He must not give up on that. Even the US public wants her to face the music. They recognise the simple injustice of letting her hide in the States, cocking a snook at victim Harry Dunn’s parents.Not for the first time, though, Boris is proving critics wrong.THE preening, entitled arrogance of ­former Speaker John Bercow was never better exposed than by him blowing £, of public money on a taxi ride.Citing wafer-thin security fears, he saved himself a long train journey by taking a cab from Westminster all the way to Nottingham to lecture unfortunate students.We take great pleasure in knowing that all of Bercow’s anti-democratic Remoaner tricks and verbose interjections were instantly negated by the Tories’ election win and the arrival of an infinitely superior successor.The Government must block any honour for him, especially the peerage he wants.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris clash donald iran huawei
story: Boris Johnson first took the US president to task for walking away from the Iran nuclear deal without offering an alternative.He insisted: “If we’re going to get rid of it, let’s replace it with a Trump deal. President Trump is a great dealmaker, by his own account and many others”.Boris then chided the US for its attack on No’s plan to ban Huawei only from core elements of the country’s G network.Senior US officials called any cooperation with the Chinese giant “nothing short of madness” on Monday as they handed over to ministers new intelligence on the potential of hacking and cyber attacks by the Chinese state.But the PM said: “The British public deserve to have access to the best possible technology.“We want to put in gigabit broadband for everybody.”Mr Johnson also faced pressure from Australia’s former leader yesterday over what do about Huawei, with a decision due by the end of the month.Malcolm Turnbull warned the UK could be “vulnerable”it uses Huawei for G.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast storm brendan wind travel
story: Further weather warnings have been issued for this afternoon and evening, with torrential rain and strong winds forecast across most of the country.The Met Office has yellow warnings for wind covering much of the UK throughout Tuesday.This will be accompanied by heavy rain, the worst of which is likely to be in southern England between pm today and am tomorrow.Travel across the UK has already been disrupted, with flights, trains and ferry services delayed or cancelled.The high winds forced airlines to ert flights scheduled to land at Gatwick Airport.Seven flights to Gatwick Airport have been erted to other locations across the UK so far, after gales in excess of mph struck the area last night.Gatwick Airport said two Wizz Air flights, four easyJet services and one Norwegian Air flight were erted.One easyJet flight from Edinburgh was forced to land at Birmingham.In Wales, more than , properties were left without power after a tree fell onto a power line in Bontnewydd, Gwynedd.The strongest gust recorded during Storm Brendan was mph in South Uist in the Western Isles of Scotland, with winds of more than mph also recorded in Wales and the Isle Of Scilly.The Met Office has issued four weather warnings across the UK including two for strong winds in north western Scotland and most of England and Wales.There is also a warning for snow and ice across central Scotland and the highlands.Met Office spokesman Oli Claydon said that northern and western Scotland will continue to be hit with high winds of mph to mph from Storm Brendon.However, a new low pressure front will cause blustery conditions for England and Wales on Tuesday, he added.Mr Claydon said the high winds and rain could lead to unpleasant travelling conditions and cause disruption to roads, trains and ferries.He added: We are looking at gusts of mph to mph with exposed coasts and the tops of hills seeing mph and maybe even up to mph.With that theres also going to be some rain, making conditions quite unpleasant.Its certainly going to be unpleasant driving conditions and could lead to disruption across many travel networks.On Monday, more than  homes were blacked out after electricity failures near Falmouth and Truro in Cornwall as the winds began bringing trees down across cables.In the Western Isles, all schools in Uist and Barra are closed and all bus services on the islands have also been cancelled.Several Caledonian MacBrayne ferry services are affected, with some services cancelled due to adverse weather and others disrupted.Northlink Ferries also told passengers there may be disruption on services to Orkney and Shetland.Gales of up to mph affected railways across the country on Monday, while drivers were advised to take extra care on the roads.After plaguing parts of Ireland, causing thousands of homes and businesses to lose power, the storm brought high winds to parts of England and Scotland.Seven flood warnings and  alerts issued by the Environment Agency remained in place on Tuesday morning.The Met Office has also issued a yellow warning of rain to cover the South East today, where heavy rain is expected to cause disruption and the flooding of a few homes and businesses is likely.Although the rest of the week looks unsettled, conditions are set to be drier and brighter at the weekend.

title: landlord accused of shocking racism
story: Ebrima Mboob, originally from Gambia, West Africa, arranged over Facebook to view a double room to rent in central London from landlord Elina Vimbsone.Mr Mboob claims that once Ms Vimbsone realised where he was from, she back-peddled by declaring: “It’s only for European people”.The -year-old – studying performing arts at the University of the Arts London – said he “could not believe it” when his viewing was abruptly cancelled because of his ethnicity.He said: “I was completely shocked at the landlord’s response and I still am today.“Growing up in England, I’ve experienced all types of racism, but this was the first time that I’ve experienced something this absurd.“What makes it even more shocking is the fact she said ‘will be brilliantyou can make the time to come and view’, but soon changed her mind once she realised I was black.“I wasn’t expecting her to even ask me about my background as I didn’t think it was relevant and she even had the nerve to say it wasn’t racist.Mr Mboob added how the ordeal has left him feeling self-conscious when cooking African food in case other people have the same perception.“She even tried to play it down by saying how she has Nigerian friends and that all their houses smell like what they cook,” he concluded.“I’ve just moved in with new housemates and I’ve developed serious anxiety about cooking around them in case they hate the smell too.”Ms Vimbsone declined to comment when approached by The Sun Online.Under the Race Relations Act it is unlawful for a landlord to discriminate against a tenant on racial grounds.The Act defines racial grounds as including race, colour, nationality or ethnic or national origins.According to the Race Relations Act, there are four main types of racial discrimination: direct, indirect, victimisation and harassment.Direct racial discrimination takes place when you are able to show that you have been treated less favorably on racial grounds than others in a comparable situation.It occurs when:Refusing to rent or let a property based on race is unlawful as it breaches section  of the Equality Act .In , Fergus Wilson – Britain’s biggest buy-to-let landlord – banned ”coloured” people - because he said they make his properties smell of curry.Mr Wilson issued the directive in an email to lettings agents Evolution, who handled some of his hundreds of rental properties.The email, which was leaked to The Sun, listed his requirements for potential tenants.One said: “No coloured people because of the curry smell at the end of the tenancy.”Mr Wilson, , who was once reported to own up to , properties in Kent, said: “To be honest, we’re getting overloaded with coloured people.“It is a problem with certain types of coloured people - those who consume curry - it sticks to the carpet.”

William and Harryaposs statement said: Despite clear denials, a  story ran in a UK newspaper today speculating about the relationship between the Duke of Sussex and the Duke of Cambridge. For brothers who care so deeply about the issues surrounding mental health, the use of inflammatory language in this way is offensive and potentially harmful. With Harry and Meghan looking to split their time between Britain and North America, it is unclear how much time Archie will actually get with his cousins in the foreseeable future. On their official SussexRoyal Instagram page, the Sussexes said they hoped to raise their little child with aposgeographic balance.The statement went on to say they would raise our son with an appreciation for the royal tradition into which he was born, while also providing our family with the space to focus on the next chapter, including the launch of our new charitable entity.Following his birth in May, until he was whisked away to Canada in November, Archie has lived at Frogmore Cottage in Windsor,  miles from Kensington Palace where George, Charlotte and Louis reside. But with the Sussexes alleged to have been discussing the possibility of quitting public le as early as May last year, they chose to spend Christmas in Vancouver, far away from Sandringham with the other royals, as per tradition.  And just days after arriving back in the UK they announced they would be stepping back from senior royal le with the intention of becoming financially independent. Harry is due to host the Rugby League World Cup draw at Buckingham Palace on Thursday before he is expected to jet back over to his we and child. The duke arrived two hours before the crunch meeting at the Sandringham estate to have a heart-to-heart with the Queen alone.  The -year-old monarch was said to be bitterly disappointed by the Sussexesapos desire to step back from public le while splitting their time between the UK and North America. Following their chat and a discussion with the three princes afterwards, Her Majesty gave her blessing for a transitional period. Her Majesty had been desperate for her grandson and his new we to remain full-time working members of the firm, an official statement said last night, but has now relented. She is said to want the problem resolved in days rather than weeks but has admitted producing a workable plan for the Sussexesapos desired financial independence has proved complex with details still being ironed out. title: darren lewis harry  meghan
story: NewsopinionDarren Lewis: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are right to put themselves firstThey are young people who want to go their own way, says Mirror Columnist Darren Lewis, millions of families have themShareCommentsByDarren Lewis:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIf they want out, howled the critics, they should give up the taxpayer cash and their positions in the Royal Family. Fair enough, said Harry and Meghan, we will. Cue the eruption. The critics want to have their cake and eat it. As in any dysal situation, they dismiss anything from the Sussexes unless it falls into line with whatever they want. Harry – forced to walk through London behind his mother’s coffin as a -year-old – can’t open up on his mental health issues without being attacked as weak. Meghan can’t breathe without being vilied for showing a lack of consideration to the Queen, the Crown, the flag and the Empire. The Sussexes are not allowed to set their own boundaries. Not when “duty” demands they are there to be pushed around.Of course, race has played a part in it. That much is obvious to large sections of black and white Britain. Yes, Camilla, Diana and Sarah Ferguson were also treated badly, but not like this. Not with the sustained vitriol that Meghan has had to endure. From her son being mocked up as a chimp to criticising her for editing Vogue – even though Prince Harry edited Radio ’s Today programme and Kate edited the Huffington Post website. Social media critics claimed bi-racial Meghan was not pure enough to marry into the Firm. The inference has always been that she doesn’t belong. She has been derided as a a, intent on wrecking the Royal Family. The so-called “constitutional crisis” is Harry and Meghan fighting back.  They are young people who want to go their own way. Millions of families have them. Kids who decide they want no part of the way things have been done in the past, children of rock stars who aren’t interested in music, footballers’ kids who don’t like sport. Frankly, the Sussexes are right to put themselves and their own wellbeing first. Of course, Home Secretary Priti Patel can’t see the problem. She serves under a Prime Minister whose overt racism is well documented. This debate, however, could yet become a turning point for our media. Most of the royal commentators stamping their feet over this are white. Most of the newsrooms covering this are largely white. The real time backlash is from black Britons with a digital  who are determined to have their say.  Angry, polarised race-baiting for social media hits is not the answer. The solution is a better ethnic mix in our media to give us an understanding of how to address this issue. Royal Author Penny Junor was left stumped on CBS This Morning when she vehemently insisted race was not a factor in Meghan’s treatment. “Did you check in with any black Britons before you made that determination ” asked the presenter. Junor was left stuttering. It appeared she hadn’t. All Meghan has done is back her husband as he chooses to move out of his grandmother’s house and fend for himself.

The bank statements for her grandmotheraposs account to Evans-Schreiberaposs were labelled as bills, care and savings. Her grandmother - who has now passed away - never knew of the theft. The former model - who worked for  Cara Delevigne and her sister Poppy in  - also handed over around £, to the father of her now eight-year-old daughter, Sam Oguche.  The defense argued that Evans-Schreiber left enough cash to pay for her grandmotheraposs medical costs and did consider her needs. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailJust one week ago a post-Christmas calm had descended on Sandringham House. Most of the family had headed home, Prince Philip was on the mend and the outrage over Prince Andrew’s friendship with convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein appeared to be dying down. So the Queen was looking forward to spending the rest of her Norfolk stay riding, walking her corgis and enjoying the outdoors. It was business as usual at the heart of The Firm. But on Wednesday evening, as the Queen was dressing for dinner, another of her grandsons pulled the trigger on a crisis that would rock the institution to its very core. The sovereign and her two heirs Charles and William were ambushed by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who announced they wanted to retreat from royal duties. Unhappy Harry and Meghan had been plotting to escape for more than  months and sealed their plan on a week’s break in Canada. In December, the Queen and Prince Charles urged the pair to hold their fire and submit detailed, written proposals before going public. But the renegade royals defied the -year-old monarch by firing off their extraordinary statement announcing they were stepping back from royal duties. The Queen knew instantly the shockwaves from this bombshell would be seismic for The Firm. For such senior royals to break away from the family, but with the intention to still cash-in on their HRH status, was unprecedented. And she feared the public, on whose devotion the survival of the monarchy relies, would never stand for it. That statement was the first shot in an extraordinary battle of briefings and counter briefings with the Sussexes’ advisors pitched against the Palace, the Prince of Wales’ aides and the Cambridges’ camp. It quickly developed into a war of attrition that revealed the true levels of toxicity between Harry and his once-close brother William. The Queen was forced to summons an unprecedented family summit to find a way forward for the Sussexes. Opinion polls in the wake of this “abdication bombshell” reveal young people now see the institution as irrelevant and anachronistic.  Yet the royals they admire and identy with are the former wild-child army hero and his actress and humanitarian we. One royal source said: “Harry and Meghan had known for some time that they were not part of the main plans and had to reconcile with that. “When the photo was released of the Queen with Charles, William and George at New Year, they didn’t so much mind the picture, it was the attention that came with it. “They knew where their place was, but couldn’t stop the obvious optics, that it was proof that they would be very much on the outside of the family... “Charles had spoken to Meghan personally on several occasions, their relationship was great from the start. He thought she was gutsy, talented and charming – and still does.  “The Queen, William and Charles are deeply hurt about the way the pair behaved, and forced them into this damaging crisis, but they know they cannot lose them.” The tension in the air before that Long Library summit at Sandringham, on Monday, proved everyone there understood its historic signicance. But what about the Duchess of Sussex, , miles away in Canada  She must have understood this was a watershed moment for the British monarchy and not just a matter for her and her husband.  Because, while it may be just  months since she joined The Firm, Meghan has had plenty of time to learn how it operates. Harry would have left her in no doubt the steps they were taking were set to cause royal ructions. We know now that the seeds of this crisis were sewn within months of the couple’s wedding in May . Meghan faced scrutiny of the way she cut ties with her father, alleged tensions with staff members and her lavish baby-shower in New York.  Harry was accused of eco-hypocrisy after urging us to help save the planet, while jetting off on private planes. But, scarred by his mother’s death and desperate to protect his we, he felt Meghan was being bullied and  vilied – and subject to racism. The pair became so blinded by their dissatisfaction and sense of victimisation, they seemingly failed to consider the hurt this would cause Harry’s loving grandmother. They secretly began setting up a rival website – Sussex Royal – and trademarking more than  items.  They reportedly started investigating mega-bucks endorsement deals, said to be helped by their billionaire pal Oprah Winfrey. A video has emerged of Harry touting for business with the Disney CEO Bob Iger at a film premier – offering Meghan’s services as a voice-over artist. That deal has apparently already been sealed, with one of the Sussexes’ animal charities profiting. Experts predict that Brand Sussex – the ultimate celebrity couple – could make half a billion pounds in just one year. But the couple’s unhappiness only became publicly apparent during a tour of South Africa in October.  Meghan told ITV’s Tom Bradby she was “not really OK” and it was not enough “just to survive” – while Harry seemed to confirm a rt with his brother. In November, the Sussexes embarked on their six-month sabbatical in Canada with baby Archie. Then, last month, Harry told his father some of his plans, prompting calls for detailed proposals to put before Her Majesty. Harry arranged to see the Queen on histo the UK. But when he and Megan flew home on Monday, he learned she was “not available after all” and was told to wait and discuss matters with Charles. Then, on Wednesday, came reports that Harry and Meghan were looking to move to Canada “for a signicant portion of the year”. So Harry decided to defy his grandmother and issue the bombshell statement. And then all hell broke loose.

Rock star Liam said trophy hunters “murder animals for a laugh”, and actor Sir David branded the killings “cruel”. Comic Bill said: “We must end this grotesque barbarism.” The Government is inviting the public to have their say on whether importing hunting trophies should be banned. The celebrities are backing the Mirror’s campaign to outlaw the vile hobby and to ban hunters from bringing their sick souvenirs back to Britain.Former Oasis frontman Liam, , said: “Trophy hunters are spoilt little brats. A government consultation is acc­epting evidence until January . A survey found % of the public want a ban on blood sport trophy hunting. England football legend Peter Shilton urged people to back the fight to end “this disgusting so-called sport”. Peter, , said: “There is no justication for trophy hunting. “There is even less justication for killing endangered wildle for entertainment. I am totally against trophy hunting.”  Records show about , “trophies” – including parts from  elephants – were shipped to the UK between  and . Some were captive-bred in South Africa’s notorious “canned hunting” farms where they have little or no chance of escape. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA man photographed his neighbour every time she left her home in a bitter -year land dispute. David Nolan, , took covert pictures of Catherine Holdich, , whenever she went outside - claiming she was trespassing on his land at the bottom of their adjoined properties. Retired engineer Noaln, was convicted of harassing Mrs Holdich over the petty dispute that left cancer sufferer Mrs Holdich with a sinking feeling in her stomach every time she ventured outside her home in Mossley, Greater Manchester. Police issued Nolan with a  warning about his bizarre conduct - but he was later convicted of harassment between  and . This week the widower, who is partially sighted, was convicted of breaching a restraining order which had banned him from contacting the victim.She made a statement against Nolan, but died last year before the case could came to court, reports the Manchester Evening News .In her statement read to Tameside Magistratesapos Court, Miss Holdich who lived with her husband Steven said: aposaposOver a long period of time I have been targeted by our neighbour Mr Nolan. aposaposOver the years have had to put up with all sorts of abuse including Mr Nolan taking pictures of me.  I live in a row of terrace houses ours being the end but for some reason Mr Nolan tried to claim the land at the rear of the houses which included land that Steven and I own. aposaposHe has targeted me but never it appears Steven. I was successful in gaining a court order to protect me from harassment and as a result I finally felt after years of being a victim I could now live in peace. aposaposI underwent a double mastectomy and due to the procedure was hospitalised there for a week. But when I ed home then my husband made me aware he had had an incident with Mr Nolan and I felt upset, I thought that the harassment was starting again.aposapos The court heard the campaign arose out a civil dispute Nolan was waging against Mrs Holdich over a strip of land which had aposaposoverlappedaposapos onto his property from her back garden.  Whenever she went out for walks with her dogs, he would take photographs of her. It was claimed he was verbally abusive towards Miss Holdich shouting and swearing at her and at one stage he did threaten to kill her. He was given a two year restraining order in January  after being convicted of harassment but was questioned by police again after an incident the following April in which he was seen gesturing at her from a window. Mrs Holdichaposs statement added: aposapos We have two dogs and I love getting out and taking them for a walk.  Due to the operation I felt cooped up and on this day felt fine and in the position to go for a small walk and it was a big event for me after the surgery and post op treatment. aposaposAs I ed I was feeling great and felt I was winning my battle and saw Steven at the fence. But at this point there was banging at the window and Mr Nolan at his rear window banging and ranting as he has over the years. He was waving piece of paper, making gestures that we should move. At that he stopped as it must have dawned on him that he had broken the order. aposaposI was distraught, upset and reduced to tears he was starting his campaign against me. I have had to endure years of verbal abuse over the years and I cannot endure anymore threats.  I get a sinking feeling in my stomach whenever I want to take the dogs out for a walk in the morning.  It is one of my favourite times of the day going out for a walk and helps me a lot and it gets me down knowing that he is going to be there. ”My le has been shaken up by the breast cancer and surgery and I feel I can’t go about my le and walking my dog.  I’m begging the courts to help me, protect me from this man who’s venting his anger at me.aposapos Mr Holdich who has lived next door to Nolan for almost  years told the hearing: aposaposCath had just come out of hospital after having a double mastectomy. She hadn’t been out properly and loved walking our dogs.  She wanted to go out and walk the dogs just a little way round the back of the property. aposaposI didn’t walk with her but went so far just to keep an eye on her outside the gate and watched her round the back. But I could see he was yelling at me from his lounge window.  He was behind double glazing but I could tell by his demeanour, he was waving his hands, shouting and  was making reference to a piece of paper in his hand. He was pointing at it and eventually gave me the two fingers. aposaposCath came up and joined me where I was stood, she looked up and said: aposnot again, here we go again.apos With everything  that was going on in our lives at the time it wasn’t something that we needed.  It was really upsetting for both the we and myself.aposapos

story: NewsMeghan and Harry remove line on website claiming theyre entitled to personal securityMeghan and Harry were forced to remove claims from website RoyalSussex that they are entitled to personal bodyguards due to their status, despite opting to quit royal firmShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  JAN NewsHarry and Meghan launched their new website last week " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrince Harry and Meghan Markle were forced to remove a line from their new website claiming they are internationally protected people entitled to personal security whenever they want. One of the key points of discussion at Mondayaposs crisis summit at Sandringham was the Sussexesapos annual security bill, which is understood to be paid for by the taxpayer. The couple, who fled to Vancouver for a six-week Christmas hiatus, announced last week they intended to give up public le and step down as senior royals. But with Harry, Meghan and little Archie planning to split their time between Britain and North America as they look to become financially independent, it is unclear how their body guards will be paid for. Launched last Wednesday, the rebellious duke and duchessapos new official website Sussexroyal contained the controversial phrasing about their entitlement.But this was deleted in a matter of hours of it going live, reports the Mail Online .The publication said legal expert Dai Davies, a former chief superintendent who led the Metaposs royalty protection unit, said naivety beggars belief.  He said they were mistaken to presume they should have round-the-clock protection when they are no longer senior royals. I have never heard of the phrase aposaposinternationally protected peopleapos, he continued. As far as I can see there is no such thing when you are no longer performing royal duties. The coupleaposs new website states that  per cent of their annual funding comes from the Duchy of Cornwall, the Prince of Wales’s private estate, estimated at around £.million.  And with their intention to relinquish the Sovereign Grant, it is understood Prince Charles made it clear he does not have unlimited funds. Harry and Meghanaposs wedding, as well as fitting out Frogmore cottage, all cost millions and it is unclear how far the Prince of Wales is willing to bank roll the pair. Any future funding is likely to impose firm rules on their commercial ventures, with the couple expected to look to make millions abroad.  Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has said thereaposs still much to discuss over the Sussexesapos proposed move to Canada. The Sussexesapos desire to move has raised questions over the costs of the coupleaposs security during their time in North America and who would foot the bill. Asked during an interview with Global News on Monday whether Canadian taxpayers would have to pay, Mr Trudeau said: That is part of the reflection that needs to be had and there are discussions going on.  Weaposre not entirely sure what the final decisions will be, what the dispositions are and those are decisions for them. I think most Canadians are very supportive of having royals be here, but how that looks and what kind of costs are involved, there are still lots of discussions to have. He said the federal Canadian government had not been involved up until this point about what the coupleaposs move to the country will involve.  There are still a lot of decisions to be taken by the royal family, by the Sussexes themselves, as to what level of engagement they choose to have, Mr Trudeau said. We are obviously supportive of their reflections but have responsibilities in that as well. The Sussexes enjoyed a general feeling of appreciation in Canada, he added. Meghan was seen in public this week for the first time since the bombshell announcement, as she boarded a seaplane from Vancouver Island.
